rulings.text: Vengeful Pharaoh must be in your graveyard when combat damage is dealt to you or a planeswalker you control in order for its ability to trigger. That is, it can’t die and trigger from your graveyard during the same combat damage step.
If Vengeful Pharaoh is no longer in your graveyard when the triggered ability would resolve, the triggered ability won’t do anything.
If the attacking creature is an illegal target when the triggered ability tries to resolve, it won’t resolve and none of its effects will happen. Vengeful Pharaoh will remain in your graveyard.
If multiple creatures deal combat damage to you simultaneously, Vengeful Pharaoh will only trigger once.

If multiple creatures deal combat damage to you and to a planeswalker you control simultaneously, Vengeful Pharaoh will trigger twice. The first trigger will cause Vengeful Pharaoh to be put on top of your library. The second trigger will then do nothing, as Vengeful Pharaoh is no longer in your graveyard when it tries to resolve. Note that the second trigger will do nothing even if Vengeful Pharaoh is put back into your graveyard before it tries to resolve, as it’s a different Vengeful Pharaoh than the one that was there before.

If your own attacking creatures deal combat damage to you or a planeswalker you control (perhaps because combat damage was redirected), Vengeful Pharaoh will still trigger. You must target and destroy one of your own attacking creatures.

Vengeful Pharaoh must be in your graveyard when combat damage is dealt to you or a planeswalker you control in order for its ability to trigger. That is, it can't die and trigger from your graveyard during the same combat damage step.

cards.name: Harness the Storm
cards.originalText: Whenever you cast an instant or sorcery spell from your hand, you may cast target card with the same name as that spell from your graveyard. (You still pay its costs.)

rulings.text: You must choose a target for Harness the Storm’s ability (if one exists) immediately after you’ve cast an instant or sorcery spell. There’s no way for that spell to be countered and then targeted by Harness the Storm once it’s in the graveyard.

You choose whether to cast the targeted card as the ability resolves. You can’t wait to cast it later, and there’s no way for your opponents to set up a situation where you have to cast the card but don’t want to.
If the spell you cast from your hand is countered in response to Harness the Storm’s triggered ability, you can still cast the target card while the ability is resolving.

Because you’re paying the spell’s costs, you can pay alternative costs, such as awaken costs and surge costs from the Battle for Zendikar block. You can also pay additional costs, such as kicker costs. If the card has a mandatory additional cost, like Lightning Axe, you must pay it to cast the card.
The spell you cast from your graveyard can target the spell you cast from your hand.
The spell you cast from your graveyard resolves before the spell you cast from your hand. It’s put into your graveyard as it resolves.

cards.originalText: Jackal Familiar can't attack or block alone.

rulings.text: "Can't attack alone" means Rejanak's Familiar can't be declared as an attacker during the declare attackers step unless at least one other creature is also declared as an attacker at that time (either by you or your Two-Headed Giant teammate).
"Can't block alone" has a similar meaning. Note that the other blocker(s) doesn't have to block the same attacker as Rejanak's Familiar.

Once Rejanak's Familiar has been legally declared as an attacking or blocking creature, how many other creatures it's attacking or blocking with no longer matters. For example, if Rejanak's Familiar and Canyon Minotaur both attack, then Canyon Minotaur leaves the battlefield, Rejanak's Familiar continues to attack even though it's now attacking alone.

An effect may put Rejanak's Familiar onto the battlefield attacking even if no other creatures are attacking. That's because it wasn't declared as an attacker in this case. Similarly, an effect may put Rejanak's Familiar onto the battlefield blocking even if no other creatures are blocking.
This card has been renamed to circumvent Jackal Familiar's type change.

cards.originalText: Cartographer of Kariro's power and toughness are each equal to the number of lands with different names you control.

rulings.text: The ability that defines Cartographer of Kariro's power and toughness works in all zones, not just the battlefield.

To determine the number of lands with different names you control, count each land you control once, but only if its English name isn't exactly the same as another land you've already counted this way. For example, if you control four lands named Forest, two named Island, and one named Mana Confluence, Cartographer of Kariro is a 3/3 creature.

cards.name: Cryptic Reversal
cards.originalText: Return all cards in target opponent's graveyard to his or her hand. Until your next turn, whenever that player discards a card, he or she loses 2 life.

rulings.text: If a player discards a card during their cleanup step due to having too many cards in hand, any appropriate abilities that trigger on discarding that card trigger. If this happens, those triggered abilities are put onto the stack and players receive priority in that cleanup step to cast spells or activate abilities (normally, no players may take actions during a cleanup step). Another cleanup step is created following that one.

cards.text: Return all cards in target opponent's graveyard to their hand. Until your next turn, whenever that player discards a card, they lose 2 life.

[-3]: Exile target card from your graveyard. Gain control of target nonland permanent if it has the same converted mana cost as the exiled card.
[-7]: Create three tokens that are copies of target creature, except they have haste.

rulings.text: You need both targets to activate the [-3] ability, but the converted mana cost of the first target is not a targeting restriction.
Unlike many similar effects, the haste ability granted to the tokens is part of their copiable values. If another effect copies one of the tokens, the new copy will also have haste.
